Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Factors Affecting the Emerging Development of Science and Engineering Scholars

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Early-Concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) will support a project that will examine a series of educational determinants that impact early demonstrated success for emerging science and engineering (S&E) scholars and assess the impacts of early research funding and training on longer-term outcomes that include employment and research productivity. The project will extend theoretical discussions focused on science and innovation policy by directing attention to an integral yet overlooked population of the S&E workforce, emerging graduate student scholars. It will trace these individuals over time to examine the factors that lead to early-demonstrated success and longer-term outcomes of both research and development (R&D) funding and prestige. The project will provide evidence to assess relationships among R&D funding, innovation, and employment, and the databases brought together will enable future research regarding the value of external funding and prestige across S&E-related career trajectories.

The investigators will bring together data about individuals who have been awarded Graduate Research Fellowships and those given honorable mention for those fellowships by the National Science Foundation, data about graduate school departments from the National Research Council's Data-Based Assessment of Research-Doctorate Programs in the United States, and individual-level data drawn from publicly available curriculum vitae and resumes to examines a series of antecedents and outcomes that help define success among emerging S&E scholars. The investigators will draw upon data collected by the NSF National Center for Science and Engineering Statistics (NCSES) in order to identify a crosswalk of a unique university-department identifier to facilitate the construction and analysis of two new datasets based on academic institutional research activity. This EAGER-supported project responded to a Dear College Letter issued by the NSF Science of Science and Innovation Policy (SciSIP) Program designed to facilitate the use of STAR METRICS, NCSES, and other databases in order to evaluate relationships among science funding, employment, and outcome metrics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summary: The centrals aims of this project were two-fold: (i) to examine a series of educational determinants that impact early demonstrated success for emerging researchers across the broad Science and Engineering (S&E) Divisions; and (ii) to assess the impacts of early research funding on longer term outcomes that include employment and research productivity.

For the first aim, we drew upon the NSF’s Graduate Research Fellowship Program (GRFP) to define an elite set of science and engineering graduate students with demonstrated research promise – as indicated by award receipt or publicized acknowledgement of honorable mention. We augmented this dataset with program-level survey data presented as part of the National Research Council’s Data-Based Assessment of Research-Doctorate Programs. Given the closeness in quality of GRFP award and honorable mention submissions, we examine whether additional factors, external to the proposal itself, mediate funding assignment. We find evidence that a series of leadership, peer, programmatic, and university characteristics are associated with grant funding outcomes for emerging researchers. Notably, faculty and student research quality improve the likelihood of award success, while the signal of being at a public institution decreases the likelihood of award receipt. Moreover, while we find that larger programs are more likely to have graduate students receive awards, the larger, lower-ranked programs exhibit inefficiencies in scaling the activity. This work presents a baseline in understanding the antecedent factors that lead to emerging researcher success.

As for the second aim, we vetted our proposed methodology for constructing an individual-level database for a random sample of emerging researchers in the Life Sciences. Before sampling, we stratified our sample by GRFP proposal status (awardee or honorable mention) and Life Science subfield (three most active) for a total of six bins. Within each bin, we randomly sampled 150 unique proposals, yielding a total of 900 student-proposal-year observations. Of the 900, 23 students appeared in the dataset twice given that he/she initially received an honorable mention and then an award or honorable mention in the following year. In total, our sample contains 877 unique individuals. We then matched individuals to data from three additional sources. The ProQuest data provides dissertation details for 697 individuals (79.4 percent). We collected initial professional placement data for 800 individuals (91.2 percent), and the Scopus data supplies publication-level data for 672 individuals (78.8 percent), yielding 5,900 unique publication observations. We then examined the effect of government funding on early career productivity. We employed a quasi-experimental research design and found that approximately $120,000 of R&D investment spread over three years improves an emerging researcher’s outcomes in terms of total and first authored academic publications. Most notably, the differential effect of receiving a GRFP increases total publications by 0.765 and first-authored publications by 0.353 within the 10-year period following the award. From another angle, the grant increased publication activity by 14.8 and 35.3 percent for total and first-authored publication activity, respectively.

Intellectual Merit: The research extends the theoretical discussion focused on science and innovation policy by directing attention to an integral, yet overlooked population of the S&E workforce – emerging S&E graduate students. Moreover, this project employed a dynamic analysis, tracing these individuals over time to examine both the antecedent factors that led to early-demonstrated success and longer term outcomes of both R&D funding and prestige. With data on the population of GRFP award recipients and honorable mentions, this dataset offers a strong counterfactual to differentiate the effect of external R&D funding and inherent research ability. At a time when U.S. science suffers under Congressional control of discretionary funding, this project offers evidence to critically examine the relationship between R&D funding, innovation, and employment.

Broader Impacts: This project was led by an interdisciplinary group of junior faculty female scholars: Alexandra Graddy-Reed – University of Southern California, Public Policy (co-PI) and Lauren Lanahan – University of Oregon, Management (co-PI). Further, this grant provided funds to hire an exceptional research team: N. M. V. Ross (University of North Carolina, Doctoral Student in Public Policy), and G. Sichinava, S. Soukpafolo, and Z. Trudo (University of Oregon, undergraduates). Ross was heavily involved in all stages of the research project and has selected to build upon this research stream for her dissertation work. As for the undergraduates, as a result of strengthening their research skills – both with building and cleaning databases and with conducting empirical analyses, Sichinava and Soukpafolo have decided to pursue graduate training. All together, we built a strong collaborative, interdisciplinary environment around this project with lively weekly lab meetings. This was truly a rewarding aspect of managing the grant; every team member was actively involved, and we all benefitted from each other’s contributions and expertise.

This work was presented at the 2015 Atlanta Conference on Science and Innovation Policy and will be presented at the 2016 Association for Public Policy and Management in November.


Last Modified: 08/18/2016
Modified by: Lauren Lanahan

For the first aim, we drew upon the NSF?s Graduate Research Fellowship Program (GRFP) to define an elite set of science and engineering graduate students with demonstrated research promise – as indicated by award receipt or publicized acknowledgement of honorable mention. We augmented this dataset with program-level survey data presented as part of the National Research Council?s Data-Based Assessment of Research-Doctorate Programs. We find evidence that a series of leadership, peer, programmatic, and university characteristics are associated with grant funding outcomes for emerging researchers.
